author: Lermontov
chapterTitle: We have parted, but your portrait
markText:
We have parted, yet your portrait
I still keep preserved within my heart:
Like a faint image of the finest years,
It still brings delight to my soul.

I give myself over to new sorrows,
Yet I still cannot forget it without feeling:
Like a ruined temple—still a shrine,
A toppled icon—still a god!

title: Southern and Northern Accents: China in Its Dialects
author: Zheng Zining
chapterTitle: How did the Nanjing-style retroflex consonants come to influence regions such as Yunnan and Ningxia?
markText: The distribution of retroflex and non-retroflex sounds offers us a rare opportunity to trace patterns of population migration. Compared with many linguistic features that are easily influenced and altered by external factors, in the vast majority of cases when two speakers of Chinese converse, even if their dialects differ somewhat in how they distribute retroflex and non-retroflex sounds, it is almost impossible for this to create a communication barrier. In fact, if one does not listen very carefully, one often will not even notice that the sets of characters pronounced with retroflex versus non-retroflex sounds differ between the two sides. Therefore, relatively few people will change the distribution of retroflex and non-retroflex sounds in their own accent just because the other person’s way of speaking is considered more prestigious. Thanks to this, although today the dialects of northern Ningxia, represented by the Yinchuan dialect, already sound strongly northwestern, a closer examination of retroflex and non-retroflex sounds still allows us to trace their origins.

markText: However, in order to maintain his own convictions, the price modern man pays is an extreme lack of introspection. They cause modern man to feel constant anxiety, inexplicable fear, and psychological confusion, driving him to an endless need for morphine, alcohol, tobacco, and food—but above all, a series of nervous disorders that deprive modern man of peace.
